key_insight: Reducing the information and uncertainty gap between privileged experts and sensor-based learners substantially improves closed-loop driving robustness; aligning what the expert 'sees' with what the student can observe is key.
problem_solved: Imitation learning in driving often fails in closed-loop because privileged expert demonstrations (with perfect visibility and low uncertainty) do not match sensor-limited student observations, causing learned policies to overfit to unattainable cues.
method: Formalize and measure learnerâ€“expert asymmetry arising from visibility and uncertainty differences between privileged experts and sensor-based students.
Minimize asymmetry during training by degrading or masking expert inputs to match student sensors, adding realistic uncertainty, and using asymmetry-aware training objectives (LEAD).
Evaluate improvements via closed-loop driving metrics in simulation to verify robustness gains from the asymmetry-reduction interventions.
impact: Practitioners get a practical strategy (LEAD) to close the gap between simulator experts and real-world sensors, leading to more robust end-to-end driving policies and better sim-to-real transfer without relying on privileged information at test time.
visual_elements: Side-by-side schematic of expert vs. student observations (larger/clean expert FOV vs. occluded/noisy sensor FOV).
Before/after bar chart of closed-loop success/failure rates with and without asymmetry minimization.
Pipeline flowchart showing expert degradation, asymmetry-aware training loop, and deployment on the sensor-only student.
Heatmap or scatter plot linking amount of asymmetry (visibility/uncertainty) to policy performance.
paper_title: LEAD: Minimizing Learner-Expert Asymmetry in End-to-End Driving
paper_authors: Long Nguyen, Micha Fauth, Bernhard Jaeger, Daniel Dauner, Maximilian Igl
